i still did not find the time to dig deeper into ocs - but ocs is supposed to be a rest api - right?

in this case i have a few remarks:
- post is to be used for creating an resource (in this case a share)
- put is to be used for updating/changing a resource
- delete is to be used to remove a resource (this is the unshare operations)

how does the data look like which is accepted by post and put and what is to be returned by the get?

i would expect that changes to a share like change permissions and expiry are done by putting an updates resource object to that url

in this case the file is the resource, that's also how the urls are designed. this resource can be shared, unshared or we can get the share status but it can't be deleted. you could argue that in this case we only have "put" and "get" calls because the resource as such always exists. so we could move from post to put for all operations.

> how does the data look like which is accepted by post and put and what is to be returned by the get?

you always get a xml back with a status code and some additional information, this is more or less completely handled by ocs. here an example for a successful post share operation:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<ocs>
 <meta>
  <status>ok</status>
  <statuscode>100</statuscode>
  <message/>
 </meta>
 <data>
  <url>http://localhost/oc/public.php?service=files&t=5d1fea2ca2b7d2b833ffc64f3b63477d</url>
  <token>5d1fea2ca2b7d2b833ffc64f3b63477d</token>
 </data>
</ocs>
```

the get than returns something like:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<ocs>
 <meta>
  <status>ok</status>
  <statuscode>100</statuscode>
  <message/>
 </meta>

   <parent/>

   <expiration>2013-09-28 00:00</expiration>
   <token/>
   <storage>1</storage>
   <share_with_displayname>users</share_with_displayname>
  </element>
  <element>
   <id>6</id>
   <item_type>folder</item_type>
   <parent/>
   <share_type>0</share_type>
   <share_with>user2</share_with>
   <file_source>14</file_source>
   <path>/upload_here</path>
   <permissions>31</permissions>
   <stime>1379345336</stime>
   <expiration>2013-09-28 00:00</expiration>
   <token/>
   <storage>1</storage>

  </element>
  <element>
```

i discussed an alternative solution with  @deepdiver1975 

the current implementation uses the path to the file as resource id, which makes it straight forward for the client and the server but it is not completely rest-style

an alternative would be to use the share id as resource id, this would look like:

- /shares 
  - get get all shares (/shares?file=/foo.txt would give us the shares for a given file/folder) 
  - post create new share

- /share/shareid
  - get get information about the specific share
  - put updates the specific share
  - delet delete the specific share

advantages:

- more rest-like
- we really operate on the shares

(possible) disadvantages:

- ids are not that intuitive than paths (clients first need to know the share id)
- server needs to translate share id to file id
- the api would lose the "expire" function for now, because expire dates are not set per share but per file. but i think we should change this anyway. so that the api can provide this function in the future again.


any opinions? i will have a look at the alternative more rest-like solution today, to see how this could work out.

@deepdiver1975  please add your comments if i missed something.

> ids are not that intuitive than paths (clients first need to know the share id)

looking at the use case of the api being used i think this is not an issue because the client has to query for the current share state (already shared or not and if shared to get the information about the share).

from there on the client will operate on the given shareid.

> server needs to translate share id to file id

which is actually an implementation detail - optimizations on the code can be added later (e.g. add share operating on the server which work on id and not only on the file/path)



> advantages:

- easier curl usage because of http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/clean_url

the last commit changed the rest resources from the file path to the share id. this was easier as i thought at the beginning and it results in a really nice rest-style api. i also added a version to the url to make it easier to introduce updates if needed without breaking the existing api
